AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: Stealth Inc 2: A Game of Clones
Original Release: 2015
Genre Tags: Puzzle-Platformer; 2D; Action; Stealth
My Overall Grade: B+
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 12-24 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: None
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Puzzle game aficionados
REVIEWI’m going to begin by stating that I have noticed a number of people report they had technical difficulties when trying to play this game.  I personally had none; from the moment I clicked “Play” until the moment I finished, I experienced no problems.  As such, I am going to move forward and actually review the game itself.  But be aware, you may have to take some extra steps to get it working (or not).

Stealth Inc 2: A Game of Clones was one of the more enjoyable side-scrolling puzzle-platformers I have played in a while.  The developers did an outstanding job of creating challenging, thought-provoking puzzles while expertly avoiding needless frustration.  The average gamer who may be interested in this should have no problem finishing the game with a little patience and diligence.  However, if you are someone who craves masochistic experiences: then you can challenge yourself to attain the “S-Rank” on every level— a feat which will require you to be fast and precise, and should grant you the frustration you desire.  Due to this outstanding game design, Stealth Inc 2: A Game of Clones should appeal to a full audience of people who enjoy the genre.

There is a large overworld map to traverse as you make your way from one test chamber to the next.  Each test chamber acts as a self-contained level which can be replayed later from the main menu for achievements or time-trials.  As you conquer the test chambers you will unlock new gadgets which will open up new areas on the overworld for you to explore.  There is a plentiful network of collectibles and secret areas to discover, if you are inclined to do so.

The atmosphere and narrative aspects of the game create an amusing and enjoyable pseudo-Aperture Science identity.  As you attempt to solve puzzles, you will be mocked and taunted by the man pulling the strings.  I found most of it to be quite humorous, and it added an extra level of playfulness which served the overall gameplay experience well.  The only negative aspect is that the lines were not voiced, but rather pop up as text against the backdrop, and sometimes you don’t feel like reading it while you’re trying to pull off a tricky platforming section.

It should also be noted that this game is the sequel to the earlier edition in the franchise, Stealth ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Deluxe.  You should feel no obligation to play the first one before playing this.  The narrative aspects of both games are very light and shallow and the general gameplay is nearly identical. However if you want to play with some different gadgets and explore some different levels, then you may want to consider picking it up.

In short, Stealth Inc 2: A Game of Clones is a well-crafted game that should appeal to most fans of the genre, whether hardcore or casual, long-term or new.  There is a lot to do, and it can easily last longer than 20 hours to surmount everything.  And if you really get into it, there is an option to construct and/or play user-created levels.

After hearing that there was a sequel coming out for Stealth ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Deluxe, I was incredibly excited. I thoroughly enjoyed the first game and thought it was wonderful. Alas, this isn't a review for the first game. It's a review for the Stealth Inc 2. I went into Stealth Inc 2 with great expectation because of my experiences from the first game. I'll tell you now that I was not let down at all. Stealth Inc 2 is a wonderful game and a fantastic follow-up to the first.

The gameplay remains much the same: manipulate various parts of the environment so that you can access terminals which you must hack. Once all terminals are hacked, reach the exit and you're done. In Stealth Inc 2, this formula is still present but also added on to. Instead of just navigating through menus to select the level you want, you must proceed through a metroidvania-esque world, solving puzzles to reach each level. Being a huge fan of metroidvanias, I love this change and thoroughly enjoy it. Scattered around this overworld are various pickups that you can obtain to unlock different hats and suits. These hats and suits are purely aesthetic, and this bit of customization to differentiate yourself from all of the other clones is a nice addition. Another difference between Stealth Inc 2 and the first game is that instead of there being a hard-to-get collectable on each level, there are clones that you must rescue. The locations of these clones range from being incredibly easy to get and almost unmissable to hidden fairly well. Finding these clones is a lot of fun, and escorting them to the exit can be quite the challenge.

As far as the audio for the game goes, it's done quite well. The music isn't intrusive, and that's a great thing when it comes to puzzle games. Just because the music isn't intrusive doesn't mean it isn't good, though. The music tracks are done quite well (especially the 8th level of each chapter"). It isn't the sort of music that will ever get stuck in your head

reviewText:
I'll write this review from my point of view as a long time high level player of SB.

Gameplay
The core changes in Stealth Inc 2 can be summed up as such
There's actually a story now which gives the clones some background.
You now traverse thru a Metroidvania style overworld in order to find and unlock the levels which are scattered across different areas.
Each chapter of 10 levels is focused on a particular piece of equipment and the new equipment introduced add a lot of depth to the game.
Unlike before whereby you unlock extra levels (e.g. 1-9 and 1-10) either by getting S-rank or collecting all the helices on all levels in the chapter, now you have to find these extra levels on the overworld.
Instead of finding helices in each level, there are now one or more clones on each level which you need to guide to exit safely.
S-ranking levels is much less of a thing now as the requirements are fairly low and I believe you no longer need to satisfy all 3 requirements in a single run to get S-rank. (e.g. You can do 3 separate runs - 1 with 0 deaths, 1 with 0 spots and 1 with the required time)
Finally there are collectible costumes hidden thruout the overworld and getting them will require you to solve some puzzles or finding them in some hidden area of the map.
Controls
The new equipment requires that you aim manually using your mouse (for mouse and keyboard players). Using teleporters from SBD as the reference point, the new control scheme requires far more dexterity as you need to specifically aim your throw. Unlike the original where you only have 3 static paths to choose from (high, middle, low), you now have the freedom of adjusting your throw arc according to your mouse position. They also introduced throw strength (e.g. single click to drop the equipment next to you, long clicks to do maximum distance throws). The most annoying thing about this is aiming while the camera moves as the throw arc changes with the camera perspective. Note that just as in SBD, the lines indicating the throw path are ultimately just guides, the actual path is actually slightly different.

In case you're wondering, yes you can remap the key bindings.

Graphics
In Stealth Inc 2, the graphics have been overhauled and it's now a 2.5D experience. However, this change is one I actually dislike as I prefer the faster response of SBD. Subjectively, I find that the movement of the player character is somewhat different from SBD. Basically, there's a stronger sense of inertia now which makes it such that changing directions when you're running is slower. When changing directions quickly, you will sometimes notice that you're moving in the opposite direction that you're facing (e.g. moving left but facing right).

There are NO graphical options apart from Resolution, Anti-Aliasing and Fullscreen/Windowed mode.

Audio
The sound isn't exactly catchy but it also isn't something you'll end up turning off. It's very similar to the original games given that it's done by the same person, Ricky Honmong. =)

Miscellaneous
There are a few key UI choices in the game which puzzle me. I could be wrong but I quote these examples solely based on my experience. The game has WADS mapped for the directional input but when you're in the menus it only responds to the arrow keys. Also once you have multiple equipment unlocked, you will use the mouse wheel to switch between them. However contrary to normal expectation, selecting the equipment will also trigger it.
There's no way to warp between each area on the overworld. This is an oversight to me. It's one thing to explore the overworld but when you know exactly where you want to go and you have to go through 20 odd rooms to get there, it gets old very quickly.
One note on support, or lack thereof. There hasn't been a single patch nor has there been any posts from the dev since the release. So check the discussion boards for issues that others have encountered before making the jump.
Conclusion
Stealth Inc 2's new equipment is very well thought out and has a lot of unexplored potential.
The story is forgettable and I'm not a fan of the overworld or the collectible costumes that were introduced as they add little to the game.
In my opinion the challenge level of Stealth Inc 2 is significantly lower compared to SBD. The leaderboards are also severely lacking any form of competition.
I'd recommend Stealth Inc 2 to the casual gamer but I suggest those like me which enjoy high level play to consider carefully before making the purchase.
Stealth Inc 2 is by no means a bad game but it's safe to say that it could have been much better.

reviewText:
I'll be honest, I only heard of this game and got it when it was for free during a sale, but I am a fan of stealth, and games that aren't too graphics heavy, so I had positive expectations.

So it's annoying when I have to give up playing this game around halfway through, because although it started off strong, the bad just piled on until it outweighed the good.

The good:
-Great use of light and dark
-Sometimes clever map design
-Puzzles often need clever solutions using multiple components, that aren't made immediately clear but also aren't impossible to figure out

The bad:
-As more and more features are included, the controls become atrociously unintuitive, and puzzles normally require quick button presses and good hand-eye co-ordination, which this game prevents. For some reason, changing the controls is not an option. Too much time spent stuck in a puzzle I know how to figure out, but can't actually execute
-While there are a lot of ingenius tricks in a basic 2D layout, the game just goes on for too long to prevent it becoming repetitive and boring
-The levels are set out in an overall world, and each level has to be found before it can be played - finding the levels and figuring out the puzzles to reach the next stage is often much harder and takes much longer than the actual level itself

tl;dr It does well in much of what it tries, but it is awkwardly controlled, too repetitive, and the difficulty varies quite a lot.

Keep in mind that I never played the first game but damn did I enjoy Stealth Inc 2. Playing this game felt like like meeting with an old friend and just having good times. From the moment I started playing I enjoyed what the game was offering visually, gameplay, and story. You play one of many clones in some twisted Mcdonalds version of Apature science. Putting poor adorable clones through brutal tests that usually get them killed. One clone decides to take a stand and just maybe, break free. The game itself is mixture of standard puzzle solving levels and in between, an over-world with metroidvania elements. You can explore, find secrets, and collectibles between levels as your arsenal of gadgets begins to expand. Speaking of gadgets, this constantly keeps the game feeling fresh and adding new elements and ways to overcome challenges. Including the games excellent level design and extremely smooth controls. Stealth Inc 2 is a welcome addition to any puzzle/platformers library. Did I mention the level editor and community content? The gripes with Stealth Inc 2 are minor, things such as not being able to pull blocks, and constant instant death scenarios can grow tiresome but most of the time are your own fault. More options would've been nice but despite this the game does look very smooth. In all, Stealth Inc 2 doesn't reinvent the wheel but it does certainly hit all the right notes. If you are looking for a solid platformer with some good replay, you should check out this title.

PC Port Quality
The game should be probably be played with a controller, as there are at least 3 analog stages to the movement system. The menus work reasonably well with the mouse and are very snappy, but if you use the controller or keyboard controls, especially in the editor, the cursor can go away making clicking things a challenge. The editor is clearly designed for a controller as well. I can see they did their best to make it work with a mouse without altering, but it really needed a redesign if they expect people to be proficient with the tools. Icons are huge, and only show the text saying what they are when selected. Hovering over does nothing, so you have to click and drag to make it show the text without selecting, and it will select whatever you're on upon release. All of these things could have been in drastically smaller hotbars/windows. The default controller mapping is okay, but the placement of crouch and interact aren't very optimal for a speedrun focused game like this. There's no controller rebinding, but to be honest that's rare and thus I and many others choose controllers like the DS4 where you have full control map anything anywhere.

The game speed is tied directly to the framerate, and their target was 60. I opened the game and instantly spotted and enjoyed the smoothness of the intro logo animation and menu responsiveness, but when I got in game I knew it was at double speed. Extremely responsive absolutely, but it makes the game drastically harder while also punishing even slightly nonoptimal movements by scaling the timer speed the same. If you drop frames, it will slow down. If you cap at 10 FPS, you could essentially play with tons of time to prefect every step and get flawless times to top the leaderboard, that is if people hadn't already hacked to achieve 0.00s. Capping framerate is bad enough, but tying gamespeed to it is often even worse. Please developers, don't do either.

Taller than 16:9 is letterboxed, while it seems that wider resolutions stretch the hud and just show less of the game vertically.

Gameplay
~IN PROGRESS~ Interesting puzzles/scenarios, and a nice hub world vs the menu-only level selection of the first game. Many if not seemingly all of the levels include AI companions that play like a co-op game would (very similar to Portal 2), so it's a shame co-op levels weren't included. It's clear the single player levels weren't made for that as there are sometimes multiple companions, they are only around for portions of the levels, and getting them to the exit is a bonus objective. That said, just more levels, even as an expansion, meant for local co-op would be great.

Presentation
It was a Wii U exclusive for 5 months, and it absolutely shows. The assets were designed for 720P, so all the Menus and HUD scale badly and lose their their sharpness with odd pixelation, as opposed to the blurring you get by setting the whole game to 720 and upscaling. Behind the HUD and Menus, the game itself seems to render at the native resolution, though the 3D character models have aliasing even with 4X MSAA set in the launcher (AA being the only graphical setting in the game).

The music I've heard is very nice, and the overall visual style is there, though the 3D character model's shading contrasts a tad with the levels.

TLDR - Summary
~IN PROGRESS~ Port issues, but the small scope helps in that respect, and the actual game itself seems engaging and charming, though frustration is sure to kick in if it's anything like the first in the series. Exclusivity for consoles hurts games as evidenced with this games needless 720P target res, and the fact that we still don't have the Ultimate version of the original game in this new engine/style, because it's exclusive to Sony platforms...

reviewText:
I love Stealth ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. I played the hell out of the original free version, made a dozen levels, played the hell out of the deluxe version, made more levels. The anticipation for this one was big.

So, how does it hold up comparing to its predecessors? Not amazingly well, unfortunately. But still a great game nonetheless.

One difference, which I must say is not better nor worse but probably worth mentioning, is the stealth aspect of the gameplay suffered a big blow. The level design emphasizes platforming, the vision cone of the enemies is not as reliable as it used to and you can't easily tell where the shadows are just by looking at the screen. What makes this dead clear is that not once while playing this game I looked at my visibility meter, I completely forgot it existed. It's almost irrelevant now.

I always thought the level designers working on stealth ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ were brilliant! Well, that is absolutely still there. Very clever, fluid and challenging. It is a rare thing for me to stop while playing a game to admire the amazing cleverness of the level in front of me and this happens frequently here.

Now for the big problem I have with the game: open world map with metroidvania elements. Why, why must I witness game after game making the same exact mistake. Any game that contains puzzle elements, like complex platforming, stealth or old plain box pushing have the same limitation: no immediate replay value. Once you solved the puzzle, giving it to you to solve again will not bring any new experience, satisfaction or challenge. Backtracking through a door you already know the combination is not a challenge but a chore. That's why it didn't work on Fez, that's why it didn't work on Thief 3 and Thief 4 and that is why it didn't work on Stealth Inc 2.

At first I was keeping an open mind about it. They have great level designers, maybe they figured a way to keep the nonlinear map an interesting aspect of the game. For a while it did, navigation was easy, one part led to another, stealth elements were rightfully kept to a minimum and so on. But inevitably the player will take a wrong turn and get lost on a map of solved puzzles and that's when the tediousness strikes. I kept desperately clicking on the map screen hoping there was a warp-to feature, so I can finally get to the next test room, the part of the game that is worth my time.

Anyway, if you can swallow this annoying aspect of the game, the test rooms are a blast! Precision platforming with interesting new mechanics being added as the game progresses all designed masterfully. There are also additional challenges as usual for replay value.

reviewText:
A worthy sequel. After the first set of test chambers, each successive set (at least so far--I just finished the third) introduces a new gadget. Along with new robots, this enables a wider variety of puzzles compared to the first game where using gadgets was just for fun (except for the Teleporter Chambers, of course). In fact, that's probably the best way to imagine the test chambers in this game--like the teleporter DLC from the first game but more variety.

The next big change is the overworld--all of the test chambers are connected via a Metroidvania style overworld. After each set of test chambers that features a gadget, you get to use that gadget in the overworld, opening up passage to the next area as well as to numerous secrets and challenges.

My only real complaint so far is that it's not as clear as in most Metroidvania games when you are missing the right item to proceed, or when you simply haven't figured out the puzzle. This is somewhat due to the nature of the gadgets--there isn't a really obvious obstacle like a different color door, for example. On the first playthrough you have no idea what the upcoming gadgets are so you can't realize, Oh

Severely disappointed in this sequel to Stealth B-astard Deluxe. It seems the devs only care about consoles now, as this is obviously a port (though the change in name to the Console-approved one gives that away).
There is no proper options menu, you can only select resolution and anti-aliasing quality, or rebind keys through a launcher before the game starts. Stealth B-astard Deluxe had Steam Cloud support, but annoyingly that is also absent from this outing. And the worst change, the game is now tied to the framerate. If I play this on my low-spec laptop, the game runs in slow-motion, with sounds playing normally but the game taking ages to move. I play it on my PC, and the game runs at unplayable extremely fast speeds. There is no VSync option anywhere to be found, so I can barely play. You have a 144hz monitor? The you're out of luck. And although this hasn't affected me, many players have had problems running the game in the first place.
It's really disappointing because mechanics like the Inflate-a-Mate look really interesting to experiment with, but the moment I uninstall this game everything I've done will be lost as they didn't add Steam Cloud support. It's like they threw it out on Steam, added some achievements and left it.
If you enjoyed the original Stealth ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, then get this on a sale. If you haven't played Stealth B-astard Deluxe (or the original free version), then try that instead. This is not a proper sequel.

reviewText: It was fun for about half an hour,  then it just got teadius and boring.  It somewhat looked as if it was going to have a story, but then it did a 360 with the protagonist going right back into the testing facility; doing pointless annoying tests for the rest of his existence; getting mocked here and there with the scoreboard system showing people who can complete the test which took you two minutes to solve in only six seconds.

Very sleek visuals with a nice concept behind it.  The character, like the gameplay, is somewhat uninteresting, but if you give it time, the game wins you over with some creative puzzle challenges involving quick movement, strategic thought, and stealth.

This game was fun for a time, but it quickly became tedious to play.  Perhaps a person with a greater aptitude for platformers than myself would enjoy the challenge, but this game does not offer the same slick moves found in games like Super Meat Boy and simply punishes the player for wanting to explore at all.  For example, if you are curious what's at the bottom of a pit where the door is closed, you jump down there, but then, you realize it's a dead end and have to restart the level from the beginning rather than simply a redo like when you die.  If you die, it seems smart enough to simply place you back at the last checkpoint, so why not just give us a suicide/redo button?

Overall, it's a good 2D stealth platforming game with a professional quality presentation.  It should offer well over the 93 minutes I played if you want to continue through the tougher challenges, but if you're like me, it's just too much challenge and not enough fun.  The character is somewhat lovable but ultimately bland and uninteresting.  That said, it's well worth the asking price, especially for a game I got in a low-priced bundle deal, because it offers a very high quality stealth puzzle experience.  Worth delving into even if you only get an hour out of it.
